cards.title: Building an ivy growth solver in Houdini (Part 1)
HOW TO GENERATE PROCEDURAL 3D TREE MODELS
ISLAND GRASS WITH PROCEDURAL FUR | PART 5
CREATING 3D GRASS WITH HOUDINI FUR SYSTEMS
GROOMING 3D GRASS AND CREATING A WALKWAY

comments.text:
* L System for trunk, gravity and leaves configuration
* convex hull for collisions

* per mettere la ramp nella gui dell'asset, scegli l'attributo ramp dal menu a lato e poi coollega il channel a dove nel network c'e' la ramp. la ramp del network deve avere un nome

* shop network incluso

* comando su forma generica del cono, lunghezza rami, orientamento, spread, bending, numero di aghi, numero ci cerchi orizzontali, quanti rami per cerchio, quanti rametti per ramo, quanti aghi per cespuglio

* uses L-System for shape of the tree without skinnig it
* lot of attribcreate to manipulate leavesmovement (point SOP)
* skinning with polywire
* SOP local network with shading

* generation of LOOKAT vector: @N = point(1, "P", @ptnum%1) -@P
* connect points with the add node, convert to smooth curve using a convert node set to NURBS
* distance function

* bend node to manipulate leaf geometry and branches shape
* when bending on vertical direction, change it a bit from {0, 1, 0} or it won't work
* setting normals with the attrib vop and a bind attribut fed into the N attribute as output
* in copy_stamp remove "transform cumulative"
* use of a red curve to change leaves size, fit01($CR, .5, .1)
* same color for branch thickness
* add bit of randomness to leaves with copy stamping based on @ptnum
* circle to make more branches for the bush

* point jitter with low poly line to have noise on trunk, create group to prevent moving from origin
* add more points after jitter with resample node
* branch rotation with fit01() based on $PT
* use of template group in copy_stamp instead of source_group
* bounding box for leaves scattering

* twist contains bending effects etc for leaves bending (difference with bend node??)
* simple plane as placeholder, alphamap later
* animate scaleup for leaves
* animate leaves bending
* every resample turns interpolation back to linear, convert node after to make a NURB
* point SOP for edge_dir enablng, then attrib vop with bind and pipe into Normals (can do with VEX wrangle)
* timeshift to offset animation
* carve for growing effect
* color ramp with $CR for scattering branches, works with the carve $PT/$NPT
* leaves rotation by $PT* 137.5
* scale leaves based on $CR
* timeshift $F - stamp("", "c", 0), c = $PT/4
* $CY name of the actual copy, variation between branches
* ofsetting branch growth with $CY

* attribute wrangle run over details, i@hasGeometry = 0; if (@ptnum > 0) {@hasGeometry = 1}
* then wire a switch with custom input and default geo
* in the switch detail("../attributewrangle", "hasGeometry", 0) to autodetect the input

OR

* npoints(opinputpath(".", 0)) == 0 in the switch for easier things
* measure perimeter and attrib promote to move perimeter from primitive to points

* when snapping curve to object, keep SHIFT pressed when adding new points
* @P +=  @N * ch("push")
* create visualizer by pressing X and the dot below the node
* curveu attribute that tells you where u are on a curve

* combination of plant wire sim + PBD sims
* moss sculpted in Maya, covered in fibres with XGen
* wire solver with soil sim as route anchor for curves all simulated

__GRASS__
* closeups with interactions: wire + fully deforms and bends
* 2nd layer: hair system + geo as 1st layer, hair moves & rotates accordingly with geo
* 3rd layer: volumetric shader in Mantra

__AUTORIG__
* take model -> derive branching structure with iterative search algorithm
* figure attachments for flowers/leaves/buds -> hybrid rig
* wire solver + library of plant anim cycles
* loading rigs into Houdini DOP for collisions heroes trees

__CREATING HIGH COMPLEX TREES__
* model branches in Maya
* add them in SpeedTree
* generate them with largest LODS
* leaves as simple cards + alpha map for textures
* back to Maya to reduce LOD: * reduce based on tree component (branch/trunk/twigs/kill leaves randomly) +
 reduce regardless the role*

__PIPELINE__
achieved with FabricEngine
* converted SpeedTree hierarchy to Maya hierarchy (ability to differentiate tree parts)
* tree hyherarchy used to produce Maya skeletons and skin clusters to animate
* texture converted from SpeedTree to MPC textures

__ANIMATING & RENDERING COMPLEX LEAVES__
* leaves as cards -> swap out & scale further down without recaching the animation
**different LODs**:
* high POLY
* low POLY
* texture with alpha map

second leaves texture layer-> leaves have overlapping UV in UDIMS, they unwrapped all leaves in a single UDIM, then painted in Mari without overlapping. each leaf has unique ID for further shading/variation

__RICH DIVERSITY IN PROCEDURAL MODELS__
* in-house tool **Bonsai** -> variation across species & within same specie
* cling tool for vines onto geometry
* huge scale difference between species

__INSTANCING & VARIATIONS__
* instancing architecture with controls to drive the per_tree variation via external variables
* variations at tree level or at leaves level

__ANIMATED VEGETATION__
* curve system in Houdini to manipulate branches, the children would follow
* point clouds for leaves location & blowing away effects (train passes)
* animation of base points for subsection of trees, skinned to curves to provide animation -> __NO cyles, NO render geo limit__
* animating leaves with noise (Habel 2009)+ XGen (Thompson 2003)
* shadows vibrant with lighting (for leaves movement)

__PREVIOUS WORK__
* Deussen 1998 pipeline multilevel with
    - terrain modelling
    - plant population based on population simulations
    - modelling individual plants with L-Systems
    - rendering scene
* commercial software: 
    - Vue 5 with ough visual feedback but *not too easy to integrate in a pipeline (rendering within Vue)*
    - X-Frog node network L-System based

__FUTURE DEVELOPMENT__
* no tree animation
* procedural LOD
* better tree shading
* improve lighting feedback
* UV uneven distribution

__IMPLEMENTATION__
pipeline with shell and MEL scripts
* **terrain specification**: either NURBS or paint /sculpt tool in Maya
* **type maps**:
    - **partition maps**: break landscapes into different regions + export tree position only for desired regions (up to 6 regions)
    - **color maps**: photoshop/3d paint tool/noise fractal texture
    - **choice of trees from library**: Maya painted tree models (high res/hero trees) or manually modelled trees
    - **trees to RIB**: MEL script to scatter points, instantiate with the **DelayedReadArchive** rman function
    - **Maya RIB exporter**: to expoort camera & surface, parent perspective & specific camera by linking transformations
* **instancing**: **DelayedReadArchive** loads the model only once when bounding box appears, loads from tree library
* **shaders**: general shader shared by all trees, opacity support to have better details on leaves, either reads from a texture map or from a color map created in Maya
* **lighting**: 2 points lighting with main big key-light as sun, fill-light for better shadows
* **shadows**: Depth Map Shadows, later broke up the scene with several lights to speed up feedback. shadow map has to be evaluated only one per shot
* **shell scripts**: 
    - export camera path from Maya as sequence of RIB file only containing *transform* block
    - moved to proper RIB using substitution TAGS
    - motion blur adding for each frame previous and next camera position

* copystamping to propagate given plants geometry
* point clouds for foliage
* terrain imported from outside
* plant tool to "drop the vegetation" onto areas
* "keep alive" features: swaying, movement, cycles to deform leaves
* highlight areas for plant to interact in sim with characters
* wire solver for deformations

* clouds and volumes for leaves
* growth algorithm
* input curves for the growth

* create font shape to be filled
* divide, resample
* tethralize to fill the volume, the growth works with edges, not points
* group by pattern, 2 groups with starting and ending points
* findshortestpath to grow things
    - cost is like a distance
    - output from any start to each end
* carve node as usual to grow it
* fuse and smooth for tweaking the branches
* avoiding areas by adding object, create group "avoid" input object to bounding object
* point vop for width, polywire to create geometry

__GEOMETRY STORAGE__
* __points__: is an array of vectors, each vector describes the coordinates of the point
* primitive is an array of vertex, each primitive can be either
    - _polyline_ (open line)
    -  _poly_ (closed line)
* each vertex is a placeholder for a reference to a point
* the normal describes which side is **up**, is given by the winding order of the points:
    - **clockwise**  is up
    - **counterclockwise** is down

__CREATING GEOMETRY__

1. create points
2. create primitives
3. create vertices
4. fill vertices with references to points

__CURVES & GEOMETRY__
* __Skeletor__: extracts branching hierarchy from mesh (Au et al 2008)
* __TreeSketch__: sketch basic shape via curves
* __Treeman__: creates mesh from sketched skeletons

__PROCEDURAL GROWTH__
* no L-Systems, too hard for artists to use
* __Dendro__: particle marching engine
    - particles on base tree geometry
    - particles can march or branch
    - each point has a lifetime used to determine thickness or leaf instancing
* shell to grow branches in
* tropism effects
* wind on leaves with frequency and amplitude
* != instances of same species by changing random seed

__RENDERING__
* 3 PRT for simplifying leaves
* stochastic pruning on leaves & twigs to determine proper LOD

__API FOR BUILDING ENVIRONMENTS__
* Python API for loading/assemble/edit structures
* provides infos such as LODs
__ VISUALIZATION__
* default as nested Maya transform node, shape node for bounding boxes
* lowest LOD for everything
* lazy build: models loaded only when queried or looked at
* later switched to KL Fabric visualization
__PER SHOT EDITING__
* if asset changes -> ask camera and change bounding box + LOD again, based on pre-set ranges

__VEGETATION SIMULATOR__
* mass-spring simulator (Ape):
    - semi-implicit integration scheme, operates on hierarchy (1 parent, all children)
    - classic edge, bending & altitude springs
* final render based on curves:
    - smooth skinning algorithm using dual quaternions
    - projections & Eulerian distance + each curve has a diameter in which scatter points and use the k-neighbour to classify vertices to tag for deformation

__VEGETATION CLIPS & DRESSING__
* clip library for every tree model (25~ s != intensities)
* implicit connection between weather conditions & sequence shot

__HERO SIMULATION__
* characters interacting with vegetation
* generate proxy guide for procedural curves, Ape to simulate contact/wind + re-conformed geometry to follow prior rendering

* convert poly to vdb
* scatter to add points or points from volume
* add sop to create new seed point for propagation
* group "infected" with f@infected = 0;
* SOP solver to simulate growth
* peak to inflate along normals

idea: you could create and attribute pscale and an attribute width.
use pscale when the camera is close to the tree and skin the curves with actual geometry. when the camera is distant polyreduce to lower quality, far away just render lines with width attribute (copy from pscale)

__GRASS__
* curves have an attribute __width__ to define the thickness at rendertime
* by default curves always face the camera
* when copying, enable the N in the 2nd tab, "enable attributes"
* leaf shader already set up in houdini
* double side shader

__VINES__
* don't use alpha and texture, slow down rendertime
* use trace SOP from alpha map to create geometry
* carve has an "extract 3D curve" toggle
* sweep has a twist toggle
* polywire with a cog to __use L-System settings__
* UV quickshade to test

__ALGORITHM__
* N attraction points, 1 or more tree nodes
* __S(v)__ = set of attraction points that influence a __v__ node of the tree: if _distance(_ __n, v__ _) <_ __di__ -> __n__ belongs to __S(v)__ where
    - __n__ = attraction point
    - __di__ = radius of influence
* if __S(v)__ != empty
    - create __v'__
    - attach __v'__ to __v__ with a segment __(v, v')__
    - __D__ = distance of __v'__ to __v__
    - direction = average of normalized vectors toward all sources n of S(v)
    - optionally add tropism with __g__ vector
* for each n in S(v) if exists at least one v so that __distance(n, v) < dk__, delete n, where __dk__ = kill radius

__INTRODUCTION__
* need for scattering primitives across large pieces of geometry
* XGen -. combination of different gen patterns & primitive types

__DESIGN__
* 4 basic modules: _primitive, generator, renderer, patch_ combined to form a __description__
* __C++__ backend, __Maya__ frontend

__GROOMING__
* interactive grooming using manipulation guides
* __reference object__ to set up grooming & apply to model
* __expression system__ with attributes as length, width, bend controlled by custom MEL scripts or procedural functions

* Dijkstra algorithm to find a path in a graph
* DLA + L-system as ways to produce natural patterns
* weight via image processing

__RECURSIVE__
* __DOP network__:
    - location = gives birth to a single particle, moves with initial velocity
    - group = for particles with life > treshhold
    - split = 
        *  activates every 15 frames
        * works on groups __parts__ & __splits__
        * creates particle in a group __splits__
* __solver__ applies frev frame to current one
* __add__ generates lines between points, removes unused points
* __vop sop__ for noise

__VEX TREE V1__
* trunk as line + group for its points
* __VOP SOP__
    - add current P to a noised one
    - simple noise with amplitude multiplier
    - multiplied with __f@ptnum/(f2numpt - 1)__ to get where we are on the curve
    - fed into ramp for user control
* __wrangle__ for branches runs over points, it's for every point of the trunk geometry
    - __ch("start")__ & ch("end")__for range of points for branches to grow from
    -  density based on __rand(@ptnum) < ch("rand")__
    - save __@P__, __angle__, __length__
    - save __x = length * cos(angle)__ __y = length * sin(angle)__
    - save __vector b = set(x, ch("gravity"), z)
    - for loop on __i__
        * create a vector __c = @P + (b * i)
        * add elevation vector
        * add noise
        * create branch
* __group__
* append same wrangle over for new generation

__VDB TREE CLP__
* __UV quickshade__ to see shading results
* __subdivide__ make it highpoly
* __vdbfrompolygons__ converts input geo to VDB
* __vdbsmoothsdf__ high density (?)
* __vdbanalysis__ find closest points
* __vdbvectorsplit__ to remove inner volume
* __VOPS int__ checks file sampled with a treshhold
* __VOP__ both filename and global used as inputs for 3 __volumesample__ blocks, then plugged in a __float to vec__ to the new position

__BACKGROUND__
* __recursive & hierarchical models__:
    - generative algorithm:
        * repeat locally defined ramified geometry over cosecutive orders of branching hierarchy
        * hard for modeler to understand generative process
        * then introduced modelling languages for generative algorithms
        * specification of bounding box and pruning of outsider branches
    - control over silhouette:
        * top down algos -> decompone plants axes into smaller segments (__internodes__)
        * silhouette is given by the reach of 1st order branches
    - limb shape: to move from 2D to 3D volumes
    - branch proliferation: "
* __self-organizing trees__
    - generative algos:
        * harmonious distribution of branches densities not achieved automatically
        * shape determined by either light or space
    - tree form: silhouette easily specified by constraining the space within which trees grow

__TREE GENERATION__
* __overview__:
    - competing for both space and light at the same time
    - seedling -> branches from buds along their supporting axes
* __bushing & sketching__:
    - space for growth with marker points
    - marker near buds to simulate natural growth
    - bush continually generates markers (uniform distribution) in a sphere
* __competing for space__:
    - branches grow in the direction determined by the distribution of buds on their supporting axes
    - axes modified by gravity
    - bud volume perception with angle and radius __r + d__
    - place markers __M__
    - remove markers from M if:
        * m in the occupacy zone of a bud
        * m age is too old
        * m still there after tree is done growing
    - remaining markers: buds compete for them
        * m associated with closest bud if m is in its sphere of influence
        * m alone remains there for next iteration
    - all buds associated to at least one m are _enabled_ which means they will produce a shoot if their vigour > treshhold
* __shoot growth__: evaluates vigor for the bud __(see notes for formula)__

* __shedding__: controlling the density of the crown and self-pruning of branches in the lower part of the trunk. Shed happens when the vigor ration < treshhold Th
* __gravimorphism__: is the _b_ factor in ___Q = bL^k___ where __b = cos^2(tau) + dsin^2(tau)__ and __d__ is the distance between branch axis and ellipse
* __gravitrophism__:  rest position for branches subjected to forces can be up, plain or down
